1403.0007_1.title: Cosmic Star-Formation History
1403.0007_1.question: Research question: How do parameter uncertainties and degeneracies in semianalytic models and subgrid implementations of galaxy formation affect the predictive power of cosmological simulations?
1403.0007_1.text: The purely phenomenological treatment of complex physical processes that is at the core of semianalytic schemes of galaxy formation (  ) and—at a much higher level of realism—the “subgrid modeling” of star formation and stellar feedback that must be implemented even in the more accurate cosmological hydrodynamic simulations (      ) are sensitive to poorly determined parameters and suffer from various degeneracies, a weakness that has traditionally prevented robust predictions to be made in advance of specific observations.

1709.09180_1.text: These models include: (a) radiative cooling flows that introduce gas dynamics and self-photoionization to CIE models ( ) (b) turbulent mixing layers, in which cool clouds develop skins of warm gas in Kelvin–Helmholtz instabilities ( ) (c) conductive interfaces, in which cool clouds evaporate and hot gas condenses in the surface layer where electron collisions transport heat across the boundary (, ) and (d) ionized gas behind radiative shocks, perhaps produced by strong galactic winds ( , ).

Research question: How do massive O stars and Wolf-Rayet stars affect the reliability of high-ionization emission lines as indicators of low-mass AGNs?

This question directly addresses the main point of the sentence, which discusses how the extreme UV radiation from massive stars can excite high-ionization lines typically associated with AGNs, thus complicating their use as AGN indicators. The question is expert-level, focused on the specific astronomical phenomena mentioned, and relevant to the content of the sentence.
1911.09678_5.text: Massive O stars and Wolf-Rayet stars can generate sufficient extreme UV radiation to excite high-ionization lines such as [Oiv] 25.89 μm (, which renders moot any attempt to use this line to select low-mass AGNs . [Nev] 14.32 μm, normally considered a robust AGN indicator because of its high-ionization potential of 97.12 eV (, 2008, 2009 is not immune either, as it can be excited by fast-shocks produced by stellar winds from massive stars and supernovae (, ).

1505.00811_6.question: Research question: What is the estimated prevalence of type-II objects with specific characteristics in the local Universe, and how consistent are these estimates across different studies?
1505.00811_6.text: In the local Universe, such objects may represent as much as 30% of all type-II objects although estimates of this fraction vary a lot between studies ( , b ).

1505.00811_7.title: Revisiting the Unified Model of Active Galactic Nuclei
1505.00811_7.question: Research question: How does the disk wind model explain the continuous accretion of cold material from the host galaxy onto the large-scale disk in active galactic nuclei?
1505.00811_7.text: The disk wind scenario proposed in ) and discussed in numerous other papers (  ) consists of a continuous large disk that is fed by cold material from the host galaxy.

1505.00811_8.title: Revisiting the Unified Model of Active Galactic Nuclei
1505.00811_8.question: Research question: How effective is the Ldust/LAGN method in determining covering factors for a significant sample of type-I Active Galactic Nuclei?
1505.00811_8.text:
Covering factors for a large number of type-I AGNs have been obtained by using the L
dust/L
AGN method (  , ).

Accretion_1.title: Accretion onto Pre-Main-Sequence Stars
Accretion_1.question: Research question: What observational evidence supports ongoing accretion processes in young stellar objects?
Accretion_1.text: These stars bear many of the hallmarks of accretion, including strong emission lines ( excess Balmer continuum emission ( , variability in accretion diagnostics (, Keplerian disks that extend to near the corotation radius ( and accretion-driven jets ( ).

Accretion_2.title: Accretion onto Pre-Main-Sequence Stars
Accretion_2.question:
Research question: How do near-infrared emission lines improve the accuracy and sensitivity of accretion measurements in young stellar objects and planetary-mass companions?

This question is expert-level, focused on the specific advantages of using near-IR lines mentioned in the sentence, and relevant to the field of astronomy, particularly in the study of young stars, protoplanetary disks, and exoplanets.
Accretion_2.text: Use of near-IR lines in particular minimizes the effect of uncertainties in extinction corrections (  , ) mitigates confusion with Balmer line absorption in the photospheres of HAeBe stars ( ) and makes possible detections for very faint planetary-mass objects (especially when high-contrast observations with adaptive optics are necessary .

Accretion_3.title: Accretion onto Pre-Main-Sequence Stars
Accretion_3.question: Research question: How effective is the magnetospheric accretion model in explaining the observed spectral characteristics of young stellar objects across different mass ranges?
Accretion_3.text: Despite its simplicity, this model reproduces the observed continuum excesses in the blue and the ultraviolet spectra of low-mass and intermediate-mass T Tauri stars, brown dwarfs, and some Herbig Ae/Be (HAeBe) stars reasonably well (   , 2003   ).

Accretion_4.title: Accretion onto Pre-Main-Sequence Stars
Accretion_4.question: Research question: How have accretion rates been directly measured across the stellar mass spectrum, from Herbig Ae/Be stars to brown dwarfs?
Accretion_4.text: Direct measurements of accretion rates have been made for intermediate-mass and HAeBe stars ( , ) down to the substellar regime ( , ).

Accretion_5.title: Accretion onto Pre-Main-Sequence Stars
Accretion_5.question: Research question: How does the accretion rate in young stellar objects scale with stellar mass, and what is the range of the power-law index observed in empirical studies?
Accretion_5.text:
The accretion rate is found to correlate with the stellar mass, logM∝M
α
\*, where α ranges from 1.5 to 3.1 (   , ).

Accretion_7.title: Accretion onto Pre-Main-Sequence Stars
Accretion_7.question: Research question: How do different methods for calculating bolometric corrections in shock models compare in terms of accuracy and applicability?
Accretion_7.text: The bolometric correction may be obtained from shock models (,  see also Section 2.3from simple plane-parallel hydrogen slab models ( , or by assuming ∼104-K blackbody emission (, ).

Accretion_8.title: Accretion onto Pre-Main-Sequence Stars
Accretion_8.question: Research question: How has the incorporation of the Hall effect in recent time-dependent numerical simulations advanced our understanding of protoplanetary disk dynamics?
Accretion_8.text: Although the potential importance of the Hall effect in protoplanetary disks has been recognized for some time ( it has only recently been included in time-dependent numerical simulations ( , 2015 ).

1612.06891_1.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_1.question: Research question: How do stellar populations, radiation from stars and AGNs, and nonthermal ISM components like magnetic fields and cosmic rays collectively influence galaxy formation and evolution?
1612.06891_1.text: A full accounting for the energy input from stellar populations (, b, the long-range effect of low- and high-energy radiation from stars and AGNs (   and the consideration of other significant nonthermal components of the ISM, namely magnetic fields and CRs (  , are probably the most promising areas of galaxy-formation research in the future.

1612.06891_2.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_2.question: Research question: How do star formation models in simulations incorporate the relationship between molecular gas properties and star formation rates?
1612.06891_2.text: Some implementations couple the star-formation rate to molecular gas properties inspired by observed connections (  ) and use a constant timescale in combination with the variable local H2 fraction (   , ) which is, however, itself connected to the H2 formation timescale.

1612.06891_3.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_3.question: Research question: How do supernovae influence the multiphase structure of the interstellar medium and contribute to galactic outflows through hot, low-density chimneys?
1612.06891_3.text: By creating the hot, X-ray–emitting phase they impact the large-scale multiphase structure of the ISM ( ) and might be important for driving galactic outflows, fountain flows, and galactic winds through hot, low-density chimneys (    b).

1612.06891_4.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_4.question: Research question: How do different galaxy-halo connection models compare in their approach to mapping observed galaxy properties to dark matter halos?
1612.06891_4.text: The methods used include halo occupation distribution modeling ( conditional luminosity function modeling (or a rank-ordered matching of observed galaxy mass functions to simulated halo mass functions (, 2006   , 2013 , 2013  ).

1612.06891_5.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_5.question: Research question: How do the mass ratios of merging galactic disks and the extent of damage to the primary disk influence the rotational speed, isophotal shape, and flattening of the resulting merger remnants?
1612.06891_5.text: Depending on the mass-ratio of the merging disks—and the amount of damage that is done to the primary disk, the remnants rotate fast or slow have disky, round, or boxy isophotal shapes and are more or less flattened (       , 2005  ).

1612.06891_6.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_6.question: Research question: How do contemporary galaxy formation simulations incorporate metal enrichment and cooling processes in the context of background radiation?
1612.06891_6.text: Most modern cosmological galaxy formation simulations allow for metal enrichment and metal-dependent radiation equilibrium cooling (for specific implementations see,    , ) of gas in the presence of the UV/X-ray background radiation from quasars and galaxies ( ).

1612.06891_7.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_7.question: Research question: How do high-resolution zoom simulations of individual galaxies contribute to our understanding of galaxy formation processes and internal structures when compared to observational data?
1612.06891_7.text: Zoom simulations of individual galaxies (at resolutions <500 pc) allow detailed investigation of the formation processes and the consequences for the internal galaxy structure for direct comparison to high-resolution observations (   , a ).

1612.06891_8.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_8.question: Research question: How have large astronomical surveys improved our understanding of stellar mass functions across cosmic time?
1612.06891_8.text: Large surveys made it possible to observe relatively accurate stellar mass functions not only in the local Universe ( , ) but also toward higher redshifts (  , ).

1612.06891_9.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_9.question: Research question: How does the hot X-ray-emitting gas in massive early-type galaxies contribute to their overall baryonic mass budget?
1612.06891_9.text: Massive early-type systems are usually embedded in hot (>105 K) X-ray–emitting gas comprising a significant fraction of the total baryonic mass (    ).

1612.06891_10.title: Theoretical Challenges in Galaxy Formation
1612.06891_10.question:
Research question: What are the key characteristics and prevalence of galactic winds observed across cosmic time?

This question is expert-level as it requires knowledge of galactic winds, their properties, and their occurrence throughout the universe's history. It's focused on the specific information provided in the sentence, including wind velocities, morphology, mass outflow rates, and prevalence at different redshifts. The question is also relevant to the sentence as it encapsulates the main points presented about galactic winds.
1612.06891_10.text: Galactic winds, with velocities up to 500 km s−1 and most likely of biconical nature, carrying large amounts of material out of star-forming galaxies (the rate being comparable with and higher than the star-formation rate) are ubiquitous not only in the nearby Universe ( 2000   ) but also at higher redshift at the cosmic peak of conversion of gas into stars ( , ).

2309.17075_1.title: Hydrodynamical Simulations of the Galaxy Population: Enduring Successes and Outstanding Challenges
2309.17075_1.question: Research Question: Which major cosmological simulations have incorporated the approach of modeling galaxy populations at flagship scales?
2309.17075_1.text: This approach has been used, to varying degrees, by several flagship-scale simulations of the galaxy population, including Illustris ( Magneticum (EAGLE ( BlueTides (Romulus (IllustrisTNG (b, b, FABLE (and SIMBA .

2309.17075_2.title: Hydrodynamical Simulations of the Galaxy Population: Enduring Successes and Outstanding Challenges
2309.17075_2.question: Research question: How do different cosmological simulations compare in reproducing the mass-dependent trends of galactic outflow mass loading factors?
2309.17075_2.text: These trends are broadly reproduced by EAGLE (Horizon-AGN (IllustrisTNG (and SIMBA  and are a natural consequence of mass-dependence of the macroscopic mass loading of outflows that emerges from their subgrid models for feedback (  see also , ).

2309.17075_3.title: Hydrodynamical Simulations of the Galaxy Population: Enduring Successes and Outstanding Challenges
2309.17075_3.question: Research question: What are the primary methods used in simulations to prevent overcooling and regulate star formation in galaxies?
2309.17075_3.text:
Popular solutions are to temporarily disable the cooling of gas, either by hand ( ) or by using an additional subgrid model to account for unresolved ISM physics  to heat gas particles stochastically by temperature increments 

 (, ) or to inject (some of) the energy in kinetic form ( , ).

2309.17075_4.title: Hydrodynamical Simulations of the Galaxy Population: Enduring Successes and Outstanding Challenges
2309.17075_4.question: Research question: How do modern or corrected SPH methods address the issue of multivalued particle pressure at contact discontinuities in traditional SPH implementations?
2309.17075_4.text: Traditional SPH implementations suffer from multivalued particle pressure at contact discontinuities that create unphysical surface tension and inhibit phase mixing (, though this problem can be mitigated via the use of various adaptations (  , cwhich have become collectively known colloquially as modern or corrected SPH.

2309.17075_5.title: Hydrodynamical Simulations of the Galaxy Population: Enduring Successes and Outstanding Challenges
2309.17075_5.question: Research question: How does the Eddington accretion rate of a supermassive black hole influence the efficiency of jet production and the choice of feedback efficiency parameters in models?
2309.17075_5.text:
However, motivated by the observation that high-velocity jets are more typically associated with accretion onto SMBHs at small fractions of the Eddington rate ( some models adopt a relatively low (high) value of ϵ
f when the SMBH is accreting at a high (low) fraction of the Eddington rate (  ).

2309.17075_6.title: Hydrodynamical Simulations of the Galaxy Population: Enduring Successes and Outstanding Challenges
2309.17075_6.question: Research question: How do the cold gas mass functions and scaling relations in the SIMBA simulation compare to those in the EAGLE and IllustrisTNG simulations?
2309.17075_6.text: Building on prior examinations of EAGLE ( ) and IllustrisTNG (, ) compared the cold gas mass functions and scaling relations of these simulations with those of SIMBA.

2104.14580_1.title: Tidal Disruption Events
2104.14580_1.question:
Research question: How has the availability of pre-peak light curve data for tidal disruption events (TDEs) evolved in recent years, and what are the key surveys contributing to this dataset?

This question is directly addressed by the sentence, which provides a count of TDEs with pre-peak sampling and lists several specific examples from different surveys, including PS1, PTF, iPTF, ZTF, and ASASSN.
2104.14580_1.text:
We now have 22 TDEs with prepeak sampling of their light curves: PS1-10jh (PS1-11af (PTF09ge (iPTF16fnl (and 15 out of the 17 TDEs in ZTF (van plus AT2018dyb/ASASSN-18pg (AT2018fyk/ASASSN-18ul (and AT2019ahk/ASASSN-19bt (b) (see 
Figure 4
 for some examples).

2104.14580_2.title: Tidal Disruption Events
2104.14580_2.question: Research question: How do the timescales and chemical composition of observed tidal disruption events (TDEs) inform our understanding of the properties and evolutionary stages of the disrupted stars?
2104.14580_2.text: Finally, it should be noted that the demographics, internal structure, and evolutionary state of the unlucky stars themselves can be revealed from the timescales and chemical composition of the observed TDEs (   b).

2104.14580_3.title: Tidal Disruption Events
2104.14580_3.question: Research question: What is the typical rate of stars scattering into the loss cone of a massive black hole, and how does this rate vary for different types of galaxies?
2104.14580_3.text:
Analytical and numerical calculations for stars scattering into the MBH loss cone (the angular momentum phase-space for which R
p < R
T, where R
p is the pericenter of the star's orbit, are in general agreement for a rate that ranges from 10−4–10−5 year−1 galaxy−1 ( , with rates as high as 10−3 year−1 galaxy−1 in galaxies with steep nuclear density profiles such as nucleated dwarf galaxies  and poststarburst (E+A) galaxies (Stone & van ).

2104.14580_4.title: Tidal Disruption Events
2104.14580_4.question: Research question: How do the observed velocities and shifts in highly ionized outflows from tidal disruption events vary across different wavelengths and events, and what do these variations reveal about the outflows' physical properties?
2104.14580_4.text: Highly ionized outflows have now been detected from spectra in the X-rays from ASASSN-14li (, and in the UV from ASASSN-14li (iPTF16fnl (iPTF15af (and AT2018zr/PS18kh (with a wide range of velocities, sometimes blue-shifted and sometimes red-shifted, reflecting a diverse set of physical conditions in the outflow in terms of their geometry, kinematics, and optical depth .

1812.01615_1.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_1.question: Research question: How can the tidal potential experienced by a particle in orbit be used to model cluster evolution through both analytic and N-body simulation methods?
1812.01615_1.text: As the particle moves along its orbit, one records the tidal potential to which it is subject and uses this to calculate cluster evolution from an analytic model (  b ) or via a direct N-body simulation ( , a, ).

1812.01615_2.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_2.question: Research question: How can the star formation rate be estimated using column density thresholds and young stellar object counts in molecular clouds?
1812.01615_2.text: The most direct is to define a column density or extinction threshold, estimate the mass within that threshold, calculate the density and thus the free-fall time from the mass and projected area (assuming the unseen third dimension is comparable in size with the two observed dimensionsand estimate the SFR by counting young stellar objects (YSOs) and estimating their masses and the duration of the YSO phase (a  ,  also see , ).

1812.01615_3.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_3.question: Research question: How has the modeling of density probability distribution functions in self-gravitating systems evolved since the initial argument?
1812.01615_3.text: The earliest version of such an argument was put forward by but this has been superseded by numerous later works that model the density PDF and the evolution of its self-gravitating parts with increasing accuracy (   ).

1812.01615_4.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_4.question: Research question: How do theoretical models, numerical simulations, and observations collectively inform our understanding of the impact of outflows on star-formation efficiencies in stellar clusters?
1812.01615_4.text: For this reason, theoretical models ( numerical simulations ( b, and observations ( , ) all suggest that outflows have a limited role in setting final star-formation efficiencies in most clusters.

1812.01615_5.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_5.question: Research question: How do stochastic effects in stellar populations impact the light output of small star clusters, and what methods are used to account for these fluctuations?
1812.01615_5.text:
More complex methods take into account the stochastic fluctuations in light output that occur as a result of partial sampling of the IMF in clusters smaller than ∼104


 ( , de , a) or add narrowband photometry targeting nebular lines (usually Hα) to provide better age discrimination ( , ).

1812.01615_6.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_6.question: Research question: How do one-dimensional analytic models of astrophysical processes differ when incorporating radiative cooling effects compared to models without cooling?
1812.01615_6.text: There are a number of analytic models describing this process in one dimension without cooling (see  for a review) and with cooling (and several authors have published 1D numerical results including cooling (  , ).

1812.01615_7.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_7.question:
Research question: What is the current debate surrounding the functional form of the stellar initial mass function at high masses?

This question is appropriate because:
1. It's expert-level, addressing a specific aspect of stellar astrophysics.
2. It's focused on the main topic of the sentence: the shape of the stellar mass function.
3. It's relevant to the sentence, which discusses different proposed functional forms and the ongoing debate.
4. It's concise, capturing the essence of the sentence in a single question.

1812.01615_8.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_8.question: Research question: How do the observed luminosities of diffuse gas surrounding young massive clusters (YMCs) inform our understanding of stellar wind dynamics and energy dissipation mechanisms?
1812.01615_8.text: The observed luminosities of diffuse gas around YMCs rule out the possibility that the wind is trapped ( , 2006, 2011and require significant leakage or mixing-induced radiative loss ( , ).

1812.01615_9.title: Star Clusters Across Cosmic Time
1812.01615_9.question: Research question: How do different simulation models compare in their assessment of supernova feedback on molecular cloud destruction?
1812.01615_9.text: Some simulators find that SNe effectively destroy molecular clouds ( whereas others find that their effects are modest compared to other feedback mechanisms ( ).

1801.06117_1.title: Origins of Hot Jupiters
1801.06117_1.question:
Here are focused research questions for the key points in this sentence:

1. How does the Rossiter-McLaughlin effect allow for measurement of projected stellar obliquity?

2. What are the advantages and limitations of using rotational broadening of spectral lines to determine stellar obliquity?

3. How do star spot crossings provide information about a star's obliquity?

4. In what ways does Doppler tomography contribute to obliquity measurements?

5. How does gravity darkening inform our understanding of stellar obliquity?

6. What role does asteroseismology play in determining stellar obliquity?

7. How can star spot modulation amplitudes be used to measure obliquity for a population of stars?
1801.06117_1.text: The stellar obliquity can be measured in projection for individual stars using the Rossiter–McLaughlin effect (,  see  for a reviewthe rotational broadening of stellar spectral lines (, star spot crossings (, Doppler tomography (, gravity darkening (, or asteroseismology (, ) and for an ensemble of stars using star spot modulation amplitudes ( ).

1801.06117_2.title: Origins of Hot Jupiters
1801.06117_2.question: Research question: How do Kozai-Lidov cycles induced by stellar or planetary companions contribute to the high-eccentricity migration of hot Jupiters?
1801.06117_2.text: Kozai–Lidov cycles driven by a star (  , a) or planet (,  see  for distinctions between planet–planet and planet–star Kozai) have been widely hypothesized to trigger high-eccentricity tidal migration of hot Jupiters.

1801.06117_3.title: Origins of Hot Jupiters
1801.06117_3.question: Research question: What are the proposed mechanisms for providing the additional heat source required to explain the inflated radii of Hot Jupiters?
1801.06117_3.text: Hot Jupiters' inflated radii require an additional heat source, such as tidal heating during high-eccentricity migration (, thermal tides caused by stellar irradiation ( or deposition of stellar irradiation energy into the interior (  ).

1801.06117_4.title: Origins of Hot Jupiters
1801.06117_4.question: Research question: How does the occurrence rate of giant planets vary with stellar mass and metallicity across different stellar populations?
1801.06117_4.text: The overall giant planet occurrence correlates with stellar mass ( peaking at 2 M⊙, ) and metallicity ( , 2003, 2004b   ).

1801.06117_5.title: Origins of Hot Jupiters
1801.06117_5.question: Research question: What recent evidence has led astronomers to reconsider the in situ formation scenario for hot Jupiters?
1801.06117_5.text: Recent studies have revisited the plausibility of forming hot Jupiters in situ (  motivated by the abundance of super-Earths, planets with masses between that of Earth and Neptune, at short orbital periods (, ).

1801.06117_6.title: Origins of Hot Jupiters
1801.06117_6.question: Research question: How do various mechanisms for generating Jupiter's eccentricity affect the distribution of stellar obliquities?
1801.06117_6.text: Different mechanisms for generating the Jupiter's eccentricity (planet–planet scattering, Kozai–Lidov cycles driven by a binary, etc.) would result in different distributions of stellar obliquities (  , a, ).

2002.04340_1.title: Streams, Substructures, and the Early History of the Milky Way
2002.04340_1.question: Research question: How do perturbations from the Large Magellanic Cloud and small-scale lumpiness affect the complexity of stellar streams in the Milky Way?
2002.04340_1.text: Recent work on streams is beginning to reveal a complexity that may require the consideration of perturbations by, for example, the Large Magellanic Cloud ( as well as a certain amount of smaller scale lumpiness, as suggested by the groundbreaking analyses of de and ).

2002.04340_2.title: Streams, Substructures, and the Early History of the Milky Way
2002.04340_2.question: Research question: How does the shape of the galactic halo vary from its central regions to its outer extent, and what are the implications for its orientation relative to the galactic disk?
2002.04340_2.text: It is likely slightly oblate in the central regions [although ) argue for spherical] and changes to a triaxial shape at large distances (, with the longest axis in the direction perpendicular to the disk ( , ).

2002.04340_3.title: Streams, Substructures, and the Early History of the Milky Way
2002.04340_3.question: Research question: How has the field of Galactic archaeology and near-field cosmology evolved in the literature over the past two decades?
2002.04340_3.text: Many excellent reviews have been written over the past 20 years on Galactic archaeology and near-field cosmology, starting with the one by ) others include articles by ) on the first stars and their usefulness in (near-field) cosmology, ) on the structure and dynamics of the Galaxy, and ) and ) on substructure and tidal debris, as well as the introduction to the Galactic halo by ).

2002.04340_4.title: Streams, Substructures, and the Early History of the Milky Way
2002.04340_4.question: Research question: How do zoom-in cosmological simulations like Auriga and FIRE contribute to our understanding of stellar halo properties and their relationship to galactic merger histories?
2002.04340_4.text: Zoom-in cosmological hydrodynamical simulations such as Auriga  and FIRE (Feedback in Realistic Environments) (or those based on N-body methods combined with semianalytic models such as Aquarius (are very useful for understanding the general properties of stellar halos and how they might relate to, for example, merger history ( ).

1402.1237_2.title: Mass Loss: Its Effect on the Evolution and Fate of High-Mass Stars
1402.1237_2.question: Research question: What is the typical range of observed spectroscopic binary fractions found in massive star clusters through radial velocity monitoring campaigns?
1402.1237_2.text: There have been several monitoring campaigns to measure the observed spectroscopic binary fraction among massive stars in clusters using radial velocities such campaigns typically find an observed binary fraction of 20–60% (     , 2009, 2012    ).

1402.1237_3.title: Mass Loss: Its Effect on the Evolution and Fate of High-Mass Stars
1402.1237_3.question: Research question: How do various energy deposition mechanisms in massive stars' envelopes contribute to luminous blue variable (LBV) eruptions, and what are the timing constraints for these mechanisms relative to core collapse?
1402.1237_3.text:
Energy deposition.

A large amount of extra energy can be deposited deep in a massive star's envelope by a number of suggested mechanisms, including unsteady burning (the pulsational pair instability (PPI , 2007other explosive shell burning instabilities (, wave-driven mass loss ( and stellar collisions or mergers in a binary system ( ). [Soker and collaborators discussed a model to power the luminosity in LBV eruptions using accretion onto a companion star (but this invokes an eruption to provide the mass that is then accreted it does not explain what initiates the mass loss from the primary in the first place.] Although any of these provide a plausible result, the main criticism for explaining LBV eruptions is that the mechanisms that are related to late nuclear burning instabilities are expected to occur only in the few years preceding core collapse.

1402.1237_4.title: Mass Loss: Its Effect on the Evolution and Fate of High-Mass Stars
1402.1237_4.question: Research question: How do binary population synthesis models incorporating Roche lobe overflow (RLOF) explain the observed distributions of stellar types and supernova rates?
1402.1237_4.text: Binary population synthesis models have demonstrated that RLOF can naturally account for many of the observed statistical distributions of stellar types as well as the relative rates of various types of SNe ( , 2007      ).

1402.1237_5.title: Mass Loss: Its Effect on the Evolution and Fate of High-Mass Stars
1402.1237_5.question: Research question: What is the current scientific debate surrounding the nature of the bright 2012 transient event in astronomy?
1402.1237_5.text: A number of detailed studies of the bright 2012 transient have now been published, although there has been some controversy about whether the 2012 event was a core-collapse SN (a a,b  ) or some type of extremely bright nonterminal event (a ).

1402.1237_6.title: Mass Loss: Its Effect on the Evolution and Fate of High-Mass Stars
1402.1237_6.question: Research question: How does the line-driven instability contribute to wind clumping in stellar atmospheres?
1402.1237_6.text: Significant wind clumping is expected on theoretical grounds (  , due mostly to the line-driven instability (this arises because the force of line driving is velocity dependent gas parcels that absorb line photons are accelerated and are therefore Doppler shifted out of the line to absorb adjacent photons).

1806.04680_1.title: Obscured Active Galactic Nuclei
1806.04680_1.question: Research question: How do complementary reviews contribute to a comprehensive understanding of AGN identification, evolution, and unification models in astronomy?
1806.04680_1.text: We encourage the reader to also consult the following complementary reviews on the identification of AGN, the coevolution of AGN and galaxies, and the unified model of AGN: and ).

1806.04680_2.title: Obscured Active Galactic Nuclei
1806.04680_2.question: Research question: How do observations of local systems and extragalactic surveys support the co-evolution of supermassive black holes and their host galaxies?
1806.04680_2.text: As discussed in Section 1.2, connections between SMBHs and galaxies in their cosmic evolution have attracted a great deal of interest, motivated in part by observations of concurrent AGN and starbursts in well-studied local systems ( statistical connections between AGN activity and star formation or stellar mass in extragalactic surveys ( and observed correlations between SMBH masses and host-galaxy properties (velocity dispersion, stellar mass, etc.  ).

1806.04680_3.title: Obscured Active Galactic Nuclei
1806.04680_3.question: Research question: How has the correlation between supermassive black hole mass and host galaxy properties been confirmed across multiple wavelengths since its initial discovery?
1806.04680_3.text: The first tentative evidence of this result was found over 25 years ago  and has since been confirmed by many studies in the X-ray, optical, IR, and radio wavebands (  , ).

1806.04680_4.title: Obscured Active Galactic Nuclei
1806.04680_4.question: Research question: How do obscured AGN contribute to the observed peak in the cosmic X-ray background spectrum at approximately 30 keV?
1806.04680_4.text:
Successful CXB synthesis models universally require a population of obscured AGN to produce the observed peak in the spectrum at E≈30 keV (see 
Figure 16
   , b).

1410.4199_1.title: The Occurrence and Architecture of Exoplanetary Systems
1410.4199_1.question: Research question: How do stellar obliquity measurements compare across different exoplanetary systems, and what range of configurations have been observed?
1410.4199_1.text: Measurements of stellar obliquity have revealed a wide range of configurations, including stars with lower obliquities than the Sun (, 33, stars with moderate tilts (, XO-3 , stars that are apparently spinning perpendicular to their orbits (, WASP-7, aand retrograde systems in which the star revolves in the opposite direction as the planet's rotation (, WASP-17, ).

1410.4199_2.title: The Occurrence and Architecture of Exoplanetary Systems
1410.4199_2.question: Research question: How do optical and infrared spectrographs differ in their suitability for studying various stellar types, particularly FGK and M dwarfs?
1410.4199_2.text: They include traditional optical spectrographs well suited for FGK dwarfs ( ) as well as new infrared spectrographs more appropriate for M dwarfs ( , ).

2010.10171_7.title: Star-Forming Galaxies at Cosmic Noon
2010.10171_7.question:
Research question: How does the conservation of angular momentum in galaxy formation persist despite various processes that can alter or redistribute angular momentum at different scales?

This question directly addresses the main point of the sentence, which discusses the non-trivial nature of angular momentum conservation in galaxy formation. It encompasses the complexities mentioned, such as baryon infall, angular momentum redistribution, and the limited incorporation of baryons into galaxies' stellar and gaseous components.
2010.10171_7.text:
Even in a population-wide sense, this finding is not trivial given that (a) infalling baryons can lose and gain angular momentum from the virial to the disk scale (, (b) angular momentum can be efficiently redistributed in and out of galaxies ( Übler et al. 2014, and (c) <15% of the cosmically available baryons are incorporated into the stellar component of galaxies (
